div.p: AMS 39, Papers of W. A. Haswell 1886-1924, Australian Museum, Sydney.

Am much beholden to you, dear Dr Haswell, for the concession made; but I find through the present enormous pressure of work in the Department, and having risen only from the sickbed at the beginning of this week,
M spent most of August convalescing after falling from a Melbourne tram on 31 July. See M to T. Wilson, 1 August 1888 and M to W. Thiselton-Dyer, 12 September 1888. that I cannot finish the essay intended for your Association, so as to reach there by Monday morning, there being no mail on Sunday.
M had evidently offered a paper for the first Congress of the new Australasian Association for the Advancement of Science, held in Sydney from Tuesday 28 August to Monday 3 September, and is writing to say that he cannot complete it in time to be read, even at the last session of the Congress, on the Monday morning. Haswell was Secretary of the Biology Section of the Congress, in the programme of which M's paper would presumably have been included. Liversidge was Honorary Secretary of the Association as a whole. The paper in question was B89.13.05, read to the Royal Society of NSW on 3 October 1888; see M to A. Lucas, 8 October 1888. I wrote to Prof Liversidge, before I received your telegram,
Letter and telegram not found. that I would finish the treatise; and if it could not be inserted in the volume, which will emanate from your meeting of this year, I would place it at disposal of the R.S. of N.S.W., should early means of printing exist there.

You must have had a most important gathering; and I am sorry that I could not be with you! In 1846 I attended as an active member the German Association,
Twenty-fourth Congress of German Scientists and Physicians, Kiel, 1846. then meeting Oersted, Steenstrup, Forchhammer, Schleiden, Dalton, Kunze, Rammelsberg, Volger, Roeper, Münter and many other illustrious men personally.
